description.content:
This is a GET request and it is used to "get" data from an endpoint. There is no request body for a GET request, but you can use query parameters to help specify the resource you want data on (e.g., in this request, we have `id=1`).

A successful GET response will have a `200 OK` status, and should include some kind of response body - for example, HTML web content or JSON data.

exec: pm.test("Website format is valid (domain check)", function () {
// Updated: Check for domain format instead of URL format
// Updated: Allow 'x' for extensions in phone numbers
// Specific value validation for known user
pm.test("User ID 1 has expected values", function () {
pm.test("User ID is positive number", function () {
// Basic zipcode validation (allows for different country formats)
console.log("✅ All user data validation tests executed");

description.content:
### Welcome to Postman! This is your first collection. 

Collections are your starting point for building and testing APIs. You can use this one to:

• Group related requests
• Test your API in real-world scenarios
• Document and share your requests

Update the name and overview whenever you’re ready to make it yours.

[Learn more about Postman Collections.](https://learning.postman.com/docs/collections/collections-overview/)

description.content:
### Welcome to Postman! This is your first collection. 

Collections are your starting point for building and testing APIs. You can use this one to:

• Group related requests
• Test your API in real-world scenarios
• Document and share your requests

Update the name and overview whenever you’re ready to make it yours.

[Learn more about Postman Collections.](https://learning.postman.com/docs/collections/collections-overview/)
